Howl's Moving Castle was the one Miyazaki film that I hadn't seen that I wanted to see most.  From the moment I saw the image of that crazy moving castle I knew I had to see this film. I wasn't let down...
Combining elements of magic, steam punk, romance, fantasy, witches and wars, this film is truly a delight on so many levels.  Dealing with politics, relationship problems, good versus evil in a world where good and evil might be one in the same, and having them all rolled into one congruous mishmash of relatability, Howl's Moving Castle is full of lessons to be learned while still delivering a magical mystery tour of a far far away place. 
The imagination is let loose in this film with vibrant colours, weird yet familiar people, places and objects and an absolutely breathtaking piece of animation.  Each character shows a slightly different design style common to different types of anime which makes them unique and yet familiar at the same time. 
Truly a gem in the Ghibli library and comes with a high recommend from yours truly. I'll be watching Howl's Moving Castle again... and soon!
I give this movie a 5 star!!!

Howls Moving Castle(2005)
Starring:Christian Bale(Howl),Jean Simmons(Old Sophie),Lauren Bacall(Witch of the Waste),Emily Mortimer(Sophie),Billy Crystal(Calcifer)
Written and Directed By:Hayo Miyazakai
My Review
If only I where in the theater watching more Ghibli films that would be lovely. When I first started out watching Ghibli movies my friend recommended I watch Howls Moving Castle but I never got around to renting it. My mother is shopping and she calls me and she says "Eddie more of those Ghibli films are in the store again I'll get you two, Which one's do you want?" I answered "Howl's Moving Castle and My Neighbor Tortoro." She came home with two more Ghbili films to add to my collection. I yet again didn't know anything about this film before I pressed the play button on the DVD. I think I'm almost done watching all Ghibli films that have been made so far I hope not, this films are very magical and breathtaking. There movies move me to an even greater appreciation for animation.
Sophie, a quiet girl working in a hat shop, finds her life thrown into turmoil when she is literally swept off her feet by a handsome but mysterious wizard named Howl. The Vain and Vengeful witch of the west, jealous of her friendship, puts a spell on Sophie.
The opening sequence is awesome, you get this lovely music and approaching in a fog is the moving castle. You meet Sophie who likes working her mother's hat shop and she meets Howl who safely guards from some foolish guard, but the witch of the waste puts a spell on her taking her youth.
This Ghibli film is based off a novel written by Dianna Wynn Jones and now I feel like reading it. The top notch animation is just as breathtaking as it is,but it's always these characters that drive these movies. Sophie has the greatest character depth that with Howl. When she changes from old and young face she changes attitude or emotion. Howl changes from man to a type of bird and all his life he has hidden from his enemies because of he's losing purpose. I give Howl's Moving Castle a five out of five.
As beautifully realized as it was, several abstract and vague elements prevented me from enjoying this fully.
Such strong performances play as such irritating characters in this clunky and confusing, yet vast and beautiful, film.
The scenery is beautiful, the characters are all unique in their own way. Great character developement as you would expect with a Miyazaki film.
Not much to say. Except that the score wasn't as epic as previous Hayao Miyazaki's films like Spirited Away, specifically Princess Mononoke, which was sort of a let-down at some point.

With the rising success of Spirited Away, the highest grossing film to ever reach Japanese history, there seemed to be a roller coaster of ups and downs.

Princess Mononoke, everybody saw.
My Neighbors the Yamadas, bought them time, and was an overwhelming success.
And Spirited Away was their grandest masterpiece that they have ever accomplished, could the cycle be stopped?

Well, Howl's Moving Castle, took a different route. Not only was this film was just as good, if possibly better than Spirited Away for some people's opinions, but it also attempted to compete with Spirited Away as well by being nominated for Academy Award for Best Animated Feature. Did it win? Nope. Which in my opinion, I'm still looking for another film to compete with Spirited Away which in my past review, is why I'm jealous of the film. Do I think it's better than Spirited Away? Eh, no. I mean Howl's Moving Castle did have SOMETHING to like about it, but, with Spirited Away's original story battling a movie that is adapted from a book, rather a novel, it's almost impossible for the film to step up to the plate to bat. Well, let's look at what we have here...

We have a teenage girl named Sophie Hatter, which is ironic because she works in a hat shop during a war, she meets a young man named Howl, who's rumored to steal people's hearts, but he's not as intimidating as people think, he's actually a respectable, nice and trustworthy man. However, the Witch of the Waste makes trouble, turning Sophie into a ninety-year old woman; the only way to break the curse is, go see Howl who lives in a moving castle. Along the way she meets a scarecrow named Turnip, a fire demon known as Calcifer, and a young boy Markle. In which Howl may in fact have a secret of his own to hide. If Sophie can break the curse on Howl, Calcifer and the castle, Sophie will be restored to her original form, and that's it. 

First off, I'm not even going to comment on the animation because it looks as much as the same as Spirited Away, its good. Cool. I have to address this because I've read a couple mixed reviews for this film. I say this, because I feel if you do not read the book, that I'd be spoiling too much, but the film in itself is a little too questioning, what I mean to say is that, you begin to ask a lot of unanswered questions, and, without knowing the source material, your kind of left hanging, I'm not so sure if I should read the book, or, know if there is something missing here. But the fact that Howl's Moving Castle needs your undivided attention is a bit of problem, it's like you HAVE TO READ the book in order to watch it. 

As a film does it hold up? Well, yes and no. There are a lot of things that work and the characters are memorable and likable, their funny, their voices are nice to listen to, especially when you have comedian Billy Crystal playing as Calcifer, who I gotta say is the funniest part in the movie. Then there is stuff that, doesn't work. Take for instance, NOT KNOWING CERTAIN THINGS as I said before you really begin to ask a lot of questions.  

The music, in Howl's Moving Castle is great, hey, its Joe Hisaishi and he brings a ballroom dance type motif to the picture and it's a very catchy tune.

The animation, great. The story, a little jumbled, but great. The characters, memorable. This is a good movie IF and ONLY IF you have read the book.

OH, yeah. Join me in my next review.... :P
